abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Completion Report
            (PCR) for the First and Second National Seeds Projects in
            India. The basic objective of the two projects was therefore
            to continue to ensure that the availability of High Yield
            Variety (HYV) seed nationwide will not be a constraint to
            agricultural development, by further developing the
            institutional structure of the seed industry and adding to
            the existing seed processing capacity. Lessons learned are
            as follows: (a) It is clear that in order to stimulate
            and/or maintain demand seeds of the self-pollinated
            varieties, new varieties meeting farmer's requirements,
            should become available on a frequent basis. (b) It is also
            clear that seed replacement rates used to calculate seed
            demand have been overly optimistic, resulting in excessive
            investment in seed processing capacity. It should be
            recognized most of the production of seed of self-pollinated
            varieties will continue to be produced by the farmer's
            themselves or transferred between farmers. (c) The
            implementation experience also suggests that in order to
            develop an effective and efficient industry it is necessary
            to conceptualize and clearly define the roles of public and
            private sector involvement in the industry given its special
            characteristics. Conclusions drawn from the projects are as
            follows: The Projects have created infrastructure and ample
            capacity to meet likely seed demand over the next few years.
            However pits' is likely that some of the processing
            plants are not satisfactorily located geographically
            ecologically. Also the existing spare capacity is under the
            control of State agencies that may not always be aware of or
            able to fulfill national requirements. While the projects
            have not succeeded in generating the economic returns
            forecast at appraisal they have helped GOI identify a number
            of key issues in the definition of the policies and
            institutional frame work governing public sector performance
            in India's important seed industry.
